abstract.para: When managing shared storage on a cluster, every node must be informed about changes that are done to the storage subsystem. The Linux Volume Manager 2 (LVM2), which is widely used to manage local storage, has been extended to support transparent management of volume groups across the whole cluster. Clustered volume groups can be managed using the same commands as local storage.

sect1.title: Conceptual Overview
sect1.para: In clustered LVM there are some parts which play different roles:

listitem.para: Coordinates disk access for clustered filesystems and administers file locking to increase performance and availability.

Enables flexible distribution of hard disk space over several file systems. LVM provides a virtual pool (volume group, VG for short) of memory space from which logical volumes (LVs) can be created as needed.

Coordinates access to the LVM2 metadata so every node knows about changes. cLVM does not coordinate access to the shared data itself; to do so, you must configure OCFS2 or other cluster-aware applications on top of the cLVM-managed storage.

sect1.title: Configuration of cLVM
sect1.para: Make sure you have fullfilled the following prerequisites:

listitem.para: A shared storage device is available, such as provided by a Fibre Channel, FCoE, SCSI, iSCSI SAN, or DRBD.
In case of DRBD, both nodes must be primary (it is described in the following procedure).
If you find the following message in /var/log/message, configure &corosync; without multiple (redundant) rings:
listitem.screen: kernel: dlm: TCP protocol can't handle multi-homed hosts, try SCTP

sect2.title: Scenario: cLVM With DRBD
sect2.para: The following scenarios can be used if you have data centers which were located on different parts of the city, country, or continent.

procedure.title: Creating a Cluster-aware Volume Group With DRBD

step.para: Create a primary/primary DRBD resource:
Set up a DRBD device as primary/secondary first as described in . Make sure disk state is UpToDate on both nodes. Check it with cat /proc/drbd or with rcdrbd status.
Add the following options to your configuration file (usually something like /etc/drbd.d/r0.res):
Copy the changed configuration file to the other node, for example:
Run on both nodes:
step.screen: drbdadm disconnect r0 drbdadm connect r0 drbdadm primary r0

step.para: Check the status of your nodes:
step.screen: cat /proc/drbd ... 0: cs:Connected ro:Primary/Primary ds:UpToDate/UpToDate C r----

step.para: Check the locking type of LVM2 to be cluster-aware.
The file /etc/lvm/lvm.conf must contain the following line:
Write the configuration to disk. Copy this configuration to all nodes, if necessary.
Include the clvmd resource as a clone in the pacemaker configuration, and make it depend on the DLM clone resource. A typical snippet from the crm configuration shell would look like this:
step.screen: primitive dlm ocf:pacemaker:controld primitive clvm ocf:lvm2:clvmd \ params daemon_timeout="30" group dlm-clvm dlm clvm clone dlm-clvm-clone dlm-clvm \ meta interleave="true" ordered="true"
step.para: Before proceeding, confirm that these resources have started successfully in your cluster. You may use crm_mon or the GUI to check the running services.
Prepare the physical volume for LVM with the command pvcreate, for example on the device /dev/sdb:
Create a cluster aware volume group:
Create logical volumes as needed. You may probably change the size (4G) of the logical volume. For example:
To ensure that the volume group is activated cluster-wide, configure a LVM resource as follows:
step.screen: primitive vg1 ocf:heartbeat:LVM \ params volgrpname="myclusterfs" clone vg1-clone vg1 \ meta interleave="true" ordered="true" colocation colo-vg1 inf: vg1-clone clvm-clone order order-vg1 inf: clvm-clone vg1-clone

step.para: If you want the volume group to only be activated exclusively on one node, use the following example; in this case, cLVM will protect all logical volumes within the VG from being activated on multiple nodes, as an additional measure of protection for non-clustered applications:
step.screen: primitive vg1 ocf:heartbeat:LVM \ params volgrpname="myclusterfs" exclusive="yes" colocation colo-vg1 inf: vg1 clvm-clone order order-vg1 inf: clvm-clone vg1

step.para: The logical volumes within the VG are now available as file system mounts or raw usage. Ensure that services using them must have proper dependencies to collocate them with and order them after the VG has been activated.

sect2.para: After finishing these configuration steps, the LVM2 configuration can be done just like on any standalone workstation.

sect1.title: Configuring Eligible LVM2 Devices Explicitly
sect1.para: When several devices seemingly share the same physical volume signature (as can be the case for multipath devices or drbd), it is recommended to explicitly configure the devices which LVM2 scans for PVs.
For example, if the command vgcreate uses the physical device instead of using the mirrored block device, DRBD will be confused which may result in a split brain condition for DRBD.
To deactivate a single device for LVM2, do the following:

step.para: Edit the file /etc/lvm/lvm.conf and search for the line starting with filter.
